title: 110_s2784
content: The Howard M. Metzenbaum ``Menu Education and Labeling Act'' or the ``MEAL Act'' is the short title of this legislation. The Act includes findings related to menu education and labeling. Congress finds that there is a strong link between diet and health, with diet-related diseases starting early in life. Increased caloric intake is a key factor contributing to the alarming increase in obesity in the United States. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2/3 of American adults are overweight or obese, with rates of obesity doubling in children and tripling in teens since 1980. Obesity increases the risk of various health problems and costs the US $117 billion annually. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a significant increase in meals prepared or eaten outside the home, with a third of calories and almost half of total food dollars spent on food from restaurants. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States. Heart disease is also a leading cause of disability among working adults and has a significant impact on the US economy. Excess saturated fat intake is a major risk factor for heart disease, the leading cause of death in the United States. Heart disease also leads to disability among working adults and has a significant economic impact. Increased sodium intake is linked to high blood pressure, which can lead to cardiovascular disease, especially stroke. Adults over 50 have a 45% chance of high blood pressure, increasing with age. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act of 1990 requires food manufacturers to provide nutrition information on packaged foods. About 75% of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Approximately 75% of adults use food labels on packaged foods, leading to healthier diets. Consumers find it difficult to limit calorie intake at restaurants due to limited nutrition information availability. Studies show that consumers want nutrition information when ordering food to make informed decisions. Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend providing nutrition information at the point of sale. The Surgeon General and Secretary of Health recommend providing nutrition information at the point of sale to help consumers make informed decisions and reduce obesity rates. SEC. 3. NUTRITION LABELING OF STANDARD MENU ITEMS AT CHAIN RESTAURANTS. Section 403(q)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include regulations for restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name. Restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations under the same trade name must disclose calorie and fat information for food items on their menus. Restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations must disclose calorie, fat, and sodium information for food items on menus or menu boards. This information must be displayed clearly and conspicuously to help the public understand its significance in the context of a total daily diet. Restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations are required to disclose calorie information for food items on menus or menu boards. This information must be displayed clearly and conspicuously to help the public understand its significance in the context of a total daily diet. Additionally, the number of calories in a serving of the food must be provided in a clear manner, with the option for written information upon request. The disclosure of calorie information for food items on menus or menu boards is required for restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations. This information must be clear and conspicuous, with the option for written information upon request. Certain food items are exempt from this requirement, such as those not listed on a menu or menu board, daily specials, and self-service facilities like salad bars or buffet lines. The FDA requires restaurants and retail food establishments with 20 or more locations to disclose calorie information on menus or menu boards. Certain exemptions include items not listed on menus, daily specials, and self-service facilities like salad bars. Additional nutrition information can be provided voluntarily by establishments. Regulations allow restaurants to voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. States can also impose additional nutrition information requirements on food establishments. Proposed regulations must be enacted within one year of this clause. The Secretary must promulgate proposed regulations within 1 year and final regulations within 2 years to allow for variations in serving sizes and food preparation in addition to required nutrition information. The Secretary must promulgate final regulations within 2 years to implement variations in serving sizes and food preparation, with inadvertent human error and training of food service workers considered. If final regulations are not issued on time, proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations. Final regulations under item (III) must be issued within 2 years of enactment. If not, proposed regulations for vending machines will automatically become effective as final regulations. The Secretary will publish notice of the final regulations in the Federal Register. Vending machine operators with 20 or more machines must display calorie information on a sign near the food sold. Vending machine operators can voluntarily provide additional nutrition information that complies with labeling requirements. States can also require operators to provide extra nutrition information beyond federal requirements. The Secretary must propose regulations within 1 year and finalize them within 2 years of the enactment of the clause. States can require vending machine operators to provide additional nutrition information beyond federal requirements. The Secretary must finalize regulations within 2 years of the clause's enactment. If final regulations are not promulgated by the deadline, proposed regulations will become effective as final regulations, and the Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register.
